content.question: In the long run, assume a firm uses both labor and capital to produce <math alttext="25" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>25</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> units of output. The marginal product of the last unit of labor being employed is <math alttext="100" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>100</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>; the marginal product of the last unit of capital being employed is <math alttext="500" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>500</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. The wage rate of labor is <math alttext="$10" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>$</mi><mn>10</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. If the firm is minimizing the cost of producing <math alttext="25" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>25</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> units of output, what must be the unit price of capital?

topic.text: 5.3: Profit-Maximizing Behavior in Perfectly Competitive Factor Markets

skill.text: Skill 2.C: Interpret a specific economic outcome using quantitative data or calculations.
